thread.title: White House Ensures Iraqis Who Helped US Won’t Be Denied Entry
thread.title_full: White House Ensures Iraqis Who Helped US Won’t Be Denied Entry

author: Jack Davis
title: White House Ensures Iraqis Who Helped US Won’t Be Denied Entry
text:
ANALYSIS: How Trump Is Changing America’s Posture Toward Iran 
“I totally agree with Trump’s executive order, but there should be a few exceptions in the Iraqi interpreters who helped our American forces on the ground and are still helping them. Those guys to me should be an exception to his rule,” Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., said on Fox and Friends . Visa ban amended to allow entry into U.S. by Iraqi interpreters who served American forces. https://t.co/FMIpPvsNlg pic.twitter.com/UwKgdGepee 
— New York Times World (@nytimesworld) February 2, 2017 
“Even people that are doing seemingly benign things in support of us — whether as a linguist, a driver, anything else — they often do that at great personal risk,” Pentagon spokesman Capt. Jeff Davis said Monday. Advertisement - story continues below 
“So people who take these risks are really making a tangible signal of support to the United States and that’s something that will, and should be, recognized,” he said. 
Defense Secretary James Mattis had also called upon Trump to amend the order, an action seconded by Hunter and fellow veteran Rep. Adam Kinzinger, R-Ill. 
“We made a promise to the men and women who served alongside us on the battlefield, and we must uphold that promise to leave no man behind,” declared the two Republican lawmakers in a joint statement. 
“We urge the President to honor Secretary Mattis’ requests, and stand up for those who stood by our military and American personnel. For the safety of these courageous individuals and their families, and in the interest of our national security, it’s critical that we make this exception and do so swiftly,” they wrote. Advertisement - story continues below
